discussion.content: not correct, Service Module allows service order to consume stock
Asset Management is not the Fixed asset module

Selected Answer: B
The best option is the Service module. This module is designed to handle service management tasks, including tracking the consumption of spare parts used by technicians during their visits

The Service module allows you to create service orders and associate them with the specific maintenance tasks performed by technicians. When spare parts are used, they can be registered against the service order, ensuring accurate tracking and inventory management.

üìä Additionally, the Service agreement can be used to define the terms of service, including the provision of spare parts. However, the actual consumption is recorded within the service orders in the Service module.

Selected Answer: C
It s C as ‚ÄúService‚Äù it s not a module

C
Create service agreement with service objects

Selected Answer: C
Pay attention to the question: ¬®You need to determine how to capture the parts consumed¬®- this speaks of configuration, hence service agreement is the best fit here.
There is no such a thing called "Service module", the correct answer is Service agreement - you capture parts in the lines of the service agreement
Service module, not the service agreement. Service agreement as a functionality does not serve the purpose of tracking consumption (those are Service tasks features).
C is correct answer. The service agreement is used to consume parts at a service.

In the service agreement form, you can capture the parts consumed. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/supply-chain/service-management/service-tasks
Also, there is a line for materials in the service agreement line example.
Service module is correct!

Fixed assets is not a correct answer as the it did not allow to post a consumed spare parts from the inventory, the provided link presents the functionality from asset management which is different than fixed asset module, correct answer is "service orders"

questions.question_text:
A company that rents photocopiers is implementing Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management.
Technicians carry spare parts in their trucks to use during maintenance visits.
You need to determine how to capture the parts consumed.
Where should you capture this information?

An organization is planning a new Dynamics 365 Finance + Operations (on-premises) implementation.
The business process demands a huge volume of transactions to be imported during peak hours. Users can always access the system.
You need to do proper hardware sizing to ensure expected performance.
Which two factors should be considered for sizing? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
A & E look correct. User characterization and transaction characterization are mentioned. B is never mentioned.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/fin-ops/get-started/hardware-sizing-on-premises-environments

Selected Answer: BE
B. Business process optimization
Optimizing business processes helps identify inefficiencies and ensures that the system is designed to support realistic and efficient workloads. This influences the hardware requirements based on how the system will actually be used.

E. Transaction characterization
This involves analyzing the type, size, and frequency of transactions. Understanding this helps in estimating the load on the system and ensures the hardware can support peak transaction volumes.

Selected Answer: AE
Data is criteria number 1 and user is criteria number 2. So A and E

A because User profile is defining who is prioritized, and E is obvious.

I think AE 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/fin-ops/get-started/hardware-sizing-on-premises-environments

questions.question_text:

You need to recommend options to ensure that customers who place online orders are not charged until the merchandise is picked up in the store.
What are three possible ways to achieve this goal? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: Answer looks correct
The module is called Commerce and not e-commerce. The Retail module no longer exists and has been replaced by the Commerce module.
Seems the given answer is correct.

choices.D: The client has integrations that depend on direct Microsoft SQL access.
choices.C: The client wants direct access to production environments.
choices.B: The client needs to comply with data sovereignty rules in a region where Microsoft Azure Data Centers are limited.
choices.A: The client is concerned about their retail stores losing internet connection and not being able to process offline store transactions.

discussion.content: I think B. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/fin-ops-core/dev-itpro/deployment/choose-deployment-type

My choice is B.

With an on-premises deployment, existing data center investments can be leveraged. Customers can also configure their enterprise preferences to meet the regulatory and compliance needs of their business, comply with data sovereignty rules in regions where there are no Azure Data Centers, or ensure business continuity in areas with limited public infrastructure.
*interfacing SQL
